1966 AUSTIN HEALEY 3000 MK III
ROADSTER HBJ8l34372. (Stock 3859).
The MK III was the end of production of the “Big Healey”
–the 6-cylinder car-- the worthy successor to the “100”
Series cars of the 1950's . With such “luxurious”
appointments as roll-up windows, pull-up top, polished wood
facia and the much more powerful 150 horsepower, twin
carburetor, 6-cylinder engine, the 3000 MK III did retain
the 4-speed manual transmission with electric overdrive and
the style, charm and sound that was all Austin Healey. Our
car was built from December 17 through 20, 1965 and
delivered new to Dusseldorf, Germany on January 5, 1966.
German delivery cars were built to the same specification as
U.S. delivery cars and, sometime over the next 20 years, the
car made its way to the U.S. It was then purchased as an
anniversary gift to themselves by a New Jersey couple in the
1980's and has been owned by them ever since. Finished in
Colorado red with original black interior—as per the car's
accompanying British Heritage Trust Certificate, the car is
as original, in excellent condition throughout and drives
beautifully. $53,000.
1960 Austin-Healey 3000 BT7

1966 AUSTIN HEALEY 3000 MK3 BJ-8 PHASE II SPORTS CONVERTIBLE. HEALEY BLUE OVER DARK BLUE, NAVY BLUE TRIM. WIRE WHEELS, 4-SPEED WITH OVERDRIVE. OLDER RESTORATION. EXCELLENT DRIVING CAR. SUPERBLY SOLID AND RUSTFREE. NEEDS EASY COSMETIC IMPROVEMENTS.

Offered for sale, from KURT TANNER MOTORCARS, is this very good, straight, solid and honest late BJ-8 “double-lamp” convertible. The 1966/67 models were the final variation of the marque's 3000 model with roll-up windows, walnut dashboard, easy folding convertible softtop, improved centershift transmission, power brakes, 150 bhp engine, revised rear suspension, and quieter exhaust system. This car was nicely restored about 30 years ago in Texas. It currently runs and drives very well. It's been mostly in storage since then and is now ready for an easy cosmetic freshening.

The body on this car is excellent with great fitting/shutting doors, and nice fitting hood and trunk lid. There's no signs of rust anywhere and the body doesn't require any repairs. The dogleg area and outer rockers were properly repaired during it's first restoration, and a new trunk floor was noted as well. The car simply could use a nice paintjob as part of it's cosmetic improvements. The car's underside is super solid with no areas of rust, with everything looking correct, rustfree, and as it should. The mainrails, outriggers, and all other frame parts look solid and straight.

The car's chromework is showing some age/staining. The windshield needs replacing. The car's interior trim looks very decent and isn't too bad, but could look a bit tired after crisp and fresh paintjob. Dashboard wood looks quite good. The car needs a softtop fitted. The steering wheel needs replacing too. The wiring harness looks good.

Mechanically, the car is excellent. The carbs have been rebuilt recently. The car's engine starts smoothly and quietly on the key with a nice and even note through it's stainless steel exhaust system. Oil pressure is 55psi running. There is no smoke or noises. The clutch, gearbox and rear axle all go about their job quietly. The gearbox shifts fine with a nice working overdrive unit and a silent first gear. Clutch and brake hydraulics work fine. The car steers, handles, rides, goes, and stops well. It would need tires.
The original air cleaners are included. The trunk area looks very good and well preserved.
Overall, a fantastic car for easy cosmetic improvement. This car is structurally and mechanically excellent and simple cosmetics would work wonders to such a lovely, well-preserved car.
Please look at all pictures and call or email with any questions.

1967 Austin-Healey MK III BJ8

If you are searching for an iconic British sports car that is brimming with classic authenticity than look no further because this 1967 Austin Healey 3000 Mark III is perfect for you. This two-door convertible features a curvaceous and sporty styling that is sure to capture the attention of anyone who sees it.
Complete frame-on restoration.
Powered by a 2.9 liter SOHC Inline-6 engine that is paired to 4-speed manual transmission with overdrive, this charming sports car is eager to get out on the road for open top driving.
There are about 3k miles on this vehicle's rebuild however its original mileage is 87k which means that this Austin Healey will provide an enjoyable driving experience for many years to come.

The Austin Healey 3000 was built from 1959 to 1967 and is the best known of the "big Healey" models. Known for their long competition history and raced at most major racing circuits around the world. The Mark III, such as this 1967 Austin Healey 3000, was launched in October 1963 and remained in production until the end of 1967.
Very few of these vehicles are still on the road. Fewer still is the number of models in such fantastic condition as this one.
This 1967 Mark III comes with excellent options and features that add value to its rich heritage. It has a natural Asian leather interior, all original glass, and stainless steel exhaust system.
This Mark III is a rare and valuable find; perfectly suited for a true enthusiast or collector of classic British sports cars.

The 3000 sports convertible Mark III was announced in February 1964 its power increased from 136 bhp to 150 bhp by a new higher lift camshaft. SU HD8 carburettors replaced HS6 units increasing the choke size from 1.75 to 2 inches. Power-assisted braking became standard instead of optional. The new car's fascia displayed its speedometer and tachometer directly in front of the driver. Upholstery was now in Ambla vinyl. The Mark III BJ8 remained in production until the end of 1967 when manufacture of Austin-Healeys ceased. Only one further car was built in March 1968. In May 1964 the Phase II version of the Mark III was released, which gained ground clearance through a modified rear chassis. In March 1965 the car received separate indicator lights.

The Austin-Healey was born from the Healey Hundred, first shown at the 1952 Earls Court Motor Show. British Motor Industry legend Sir Leonard Lord, soon convinced Healey that Austin should build the car and thus gave birth to the Austin-Healey 100. The Austin-Healey's design and appeal as a true British Sports Car, resulted in strong sales across the globe in the late 1950's and early 60's. Over time the design and drive train matured to the 6-cylinder Austin-Healey 3000, which featured a more comfortable interior, improved braking, and suspension. 1967 would marque the last production model year of the Austin-Healey 3000, the last of the great "big Healeys" and is considered by many to be the pinnacle of the Austin-Healey brand.

The 1967 Austin-Healey 3000 BJ8 Mark III Convertible featured here is finished in classic and desirable British Racing Green with an impeccably kept original black interior. This magnificent motorcar has been beautifully restored; it is now ready to be driven and enjoyed. Worldwide Vintage Autos is pleased to present this 1962 Austin Healey.
HISTORY

The Austin-Healey 3000 is a British sports car built from 1959 to 1967. It is the best known of the "big Healey" models. The car's bodywork was made by Jensen Motors and the vehicles were assembled at BMC's Abingdon works, alongside the corporation's MG models.
During its production life, the car transitioned from an open sports car, albeit with a child-transporting 2+2 option, to a sports convertible. SOURCE:  WIKIPEDIA
SPECIFICS / BUILD INFORMATION
Certificate of Authenticity from the British Motor Industry Heritage Trust?.
This rare vehcile was shipped to Portland Oregon when new and has remained in Oregon for almost all of its life.?
Rust free example of a rare car.

1962 was the last year of true roadster body style, first year of the vertilcle grille, first year of the center shift transmission and only 1 of 2 years (1961 and 1962) featuring Triple Carburetors. SOURCE:  WIKIPEDIA
EXTERIOR
-Rust free example of a rare car. These vehicles are prone to rust issues and rarely do you see any in the condition.
-Exterior was restored using the correct materials and is show ready.
-Bumpers, Wheels and Tires, side curtains, etc have all been freshend along with new door panels and steering wheel.
INTERIOR
-Interior has been completely gone through during restoration and looks immaculate.
MECHANICAL
-The numbers matching motor drives like a dream and is ready to show or go.
-This vehichle runs extremely well, has great compression and the overdrive works well.

CLASSIC CAR RESTORATIONS:

The term "restoration" in context to the vintage car world has taken on a definition of its own. For some people, a restoration is simply painting a car and replacing items as needed, while for others, restoration means an extensive disassembly and overhaul, with each piece getting rebuilt or replaced.

As a consumer, it's important to understand the basics of restoration levels for it can impact classic car values substantially. There are hundreds of ways to “restore” a vintage car or truck including but not limited to the following: i).
Frame off restoration.
Body of vehicle is completely taken off the frame and restoration includes body, frame, floor pans (top and bottom), etc. these restorations tend to be extensive and costly. ii).
Rotisserie restoration.

These restorations are when the body (or body and frame on a unibody vehicle) are disassembled and restored utilizing a rotisserie. Body of vehicle is completely taken off the frame and restoration includes body, frame, floor pans (top and bottom), etc. these restorations tend to be extensive and costly and iii).
Cosmetic or “driver quality” restoration.

These restoration are typically limited to cosmetic items including paint and body, interior, trim and emblems, etc. Within the three levels or restoration mentioned above, there can be varying quality from an “in the garage / amateur” restoration to a high dollar professional “concours” restoration. There is a universal 100 point grading system rating classic car conditions ranging from 100 being excellent to 20 being unrestorable.
In addition to the levels of restoration above, it's important to understand the type of restoration as well for it can also impact value substantially. Type of restorations include: i).
Factory or stock restoration.

This type of restoration is geared towards restoring the car or truck to stock specs from the factory as if it were new. These types of restorations use original or oem (original equipment manufacturer) where possible. Factory original restorations tend to bring the highest dollars from collectors. ii).
Custom restoration.

These types of restorations are geared towards builder preference over factory stock. These can be refereed to as “customs” or “hot rods”. Typically these vehicles will have custom paint work, aftermarket wheels, suspension upgrades, power plant transplants, etc. A specific sector of custom restoration vehicles is “pro-touring” or “restomod / restomods” which are custom built with a more modern street performance and creature comforts than the original factory vehicle.
Please note that WWVA is not a restoration shop nor do we restore vehicles to any degree.
For questions on what type or level of restoration of any of our vehicles in inventory please call our vintage sales expert today at 1-877-422-2940.
